title: Blacksmith's Shop

images.altText: A stone and wooden cabin with red chimney stacks next to a parking lot.
images.title: Camp Round Meadow Blacksmith Shop
images.caption: The Blacksmith shop was constructed in 1936 by the Civilian Conservation Corps.

bodyText: Part of the larger complex that is Camp Round Meadow, the Blacksmith Shop serves as a unique place to learn about the history and importance of the blacksmithing industry.
audioDescription: A stone and wooden cabin with red chimney stacks next to a parking lot.

title: Blue Blazes Whiskey Still

images.altText: A large metal cauldron on top of a stone furnace draining into a wooden barrel
images.title: Blue Blazes Still Exhibit
images.caption: The Blue Blazes Still is a popular short hike accessible from the Visitor Center

bodyText: While the Whiskey Still exhibit may not be the same size as the massive operation that once stood along the banks of Blue Blazes Run in the 1920s, the new Blue Blazes still is more typical of the smaller moonshine still of an earlier day. Moonshining was a way of life in the Appalachians and the production of whiskey was an important source of income.
audioDescription: A large metal cauldron on top of a stone furnace draining into a wooden barrel.

title: Blue Blazes: A Fatal Shootout

images.altText: A black and white wayside panel along a forested trail, describing historical events of a police rai
images.title: A Fatal Shootout
images.caption: The Blue Blazes was the scene of a tragic face off between moonshiners and police.

bodyText: The evening of July 31, 1929 would end in tragedy along Blue Blazes Run. While the police were able to raid and capture the whiskey still along the stream, the moonshiners would not go without a fight. Deputy Clyde Hauver would lose his life in the fire fight.
audioDescription: A black and white wayside panel along a forested trail, describing historical events of a police raid.

title: Blue Blazes: Brook Trout

images.altText: A wayside panel along a stream, describing the ecology of brook trout.
images.title: Brook Trout
images.caption: Blue Blazes Run is clean enough to support brook trout.

bodyText: Brook trout are the only native species of trout in the State of Maryland. These sensitive salmonoids can be found in cold, swift-flowing streams. In the waters that they patrol, they are the top predators of the aqautic food web.
audioDescription: A wayside panel along a stream, describing the ecology of brook trout.

title: Blue Blazes: Signs of a Healthy Stream

images.altText: A wayside panel describing healthy stream traits, standing next to a stream in a forest.
images.title: Signs of a Healthy Stream
images.caption: The Blue Blazes has some of the cleanest water on the mountain.

bodyText: Water feeds life and Blue Blazes Run has some of the cleanest water in the park, sustaining a healthy stream community. Surrounded by a forest that filters out the water converging into the stream, the Blue Blazes provides important habitat for many sensitive macroinvertebrate species.
audioDescription: A wayside panel describing healthy stream traits, standing next to a stream in a forest.

title: Blue Blazes: The Discovery

images.altText: A wayside panel in a forest along a stream, describing the historic whiskey still.
images.title: Blue Blazes Still
images.caption: The Blue Blazes still was a massive illegal whiskey operation.

bodyText: The Blue Blazes Still was massive. It was a large commercial operation, a "steamer" still. Thousands of gallons of mash were found in 18 vats of 500 gallon capacity each. The largest whiskey still operation in Frederick County.
audioDescription: A wayside panel along a forested stream, describing the Blue Blazes Whiskey Still.

title: Blue Ridge Summit Overlook

images.altText: Rough boulders and tall tree trunks frame an overlook showing distant valleys.
images.title: Blue Ridge Summit
images.caption: This overlook faces North into Pennsylvania.

bodyText: The Blue Ridge Summit Overlook is the most accessible high vista point in the park The trail leaves from Hog Rock Parking Area and is a short, gradual climb to the vista. This vista offers a beautiful view to the north of the Harbaugh Valley and mountains of southern Pennsylvnia. The valleys and slopes seen to the north drain into Owens Creek.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 10: The Stone Wall

images.altText: A line of stones in a forest clearing, covered in plant growth.
images.title: Brown's Farm Stone Wall
images.caption: What used to be a farm boundary, now serves as habitat.

bodyText: What remains of the farm boundaries of the Brown Family's homestead has gradually been reclaimed by the forest. The stone walls, made from Catoctin Greenstone (Metabasalt), now act as shelter for chipmunks, insects, spiders, and snakes.
audioDescription: A line of stones in a forest clearing, covered in plant growth.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 11: Food and Shelter

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reading "food and shelter" standing in front of a forest grove.
images.title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 11
images.caption: The forest is a bountiful provider.

bodyText: As the forest around the Brown's Farm Trail changes, so does the wildlife. As the pine trees in the grove grow taller and hardwoods join them, new species of animal as gradually drawn to the area as otheres which prefer open areas move out.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign reading "food and shelter" standing in front of a forest grove.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 12: The Spring

images.altText: A springhead with water coming up from the ground and flowing through a wetland into a stream.
images.title: Brown's Farm Spring
images.caption: Springs are the source of many streams in the park.

bodyText: All streams start somewhere. Springheads like this one along the Brown's Farm Trail are common all across the mountian. Groundwater rises above, breaking the surface, entering into headwaters of the larger watershed. This springs are an excelent habitat for many freshwater invertebrates and amphibians.
audioDescription: A springhead with water coming up from the ground and flowing through a wetland into a stream.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 2: Wetlands

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reading "wetlands" with a "2" label.
images.title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 2: The Wetlands
images.caption: Wetlands across the mountain provide important habitat for plants and animals.

bodyText: Wetlands, found along the Brown's Farm Trail and across the park, are fed by groundwater. A wetland is defined by the following characteristics: the water table saturates the soil for at least 10-14 days during the growing season, the substrate is comprised primarily of hydric soils, and the presence of hydrophytic plants.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign reading "wetlands" with a "2" label.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 3: The Streambed

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reading "streambed," standing next to a flowing stream.
images.title: Brown's Farm Stream
images.caption: Many small, spring-fed streams flow through Catoctin's forests.

bodyText: Fed by springs throughout the park, the headwaters throughout the Owen's Creek Watershed are made up of small feeder streams leading into Owens Creek. The water, kept cool by the forest canopy and filtered by the surrounding wetlands, is clean enough to suppport brook trout.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign reading "streambed," standing next to a flowing stream.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 4: Invasive Plants

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign reading "Invasive Plants" with the number 4 above.
images.title: Brown's Farm Stop 4
images.caption: Stop number 4 on the Brown's Farm Loop shows you what invasive plants in the park look like.

bodyText: Invasive plant species are a problem for forest ecosystems. Fast-growing species such as the multiflora rose behind this trail stop can choke out the forest understory, preventing native species from gaining a foothold.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "Invasive Plants" with the number 4 above.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 5: Cycle of Life

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign reading "Cycle of Life" with the number 5 above.
images.title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 5
images.caption: Trees in the forest provide many uses, both dead and alive.

bodyText: The forest is an interconnected web of life. The trees provide the essntial base of many ecological relationships, even in death the trees along the Brown's Farm Loop provide shelter and nutrients for a wide variety of species which will later foster new growth.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "Cycle of Life" with the number 5 above.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 6: The Pine Grove

images.altText: Tall pine trees growing skyward.
images.title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 6
images.caption: Pines help control erosion and provide shelter for wildlife.

bodyText: The grove of pines that stand here today were planted by Frederick County schools back in 1957. Since the saplings were planted, the trees have grown and created a protective canopy to the forest floor below. The pines provide a sanctaury for many species as well as food.
audioDescription: A grove of tall pine trees growing skyward.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 7: The Farmhouse

images.altText: A old stone foundation in a level, hollowed out section of ground with a sign reading "farmhouse."
images.title: The Brown Family's Farmhouse
images.caption: At the start of the 20th century, the Brown Family had their homestead on the mountainside.

bodyText: Prior to the mountain being heavily forested, farmsteads were a common sight. The Brown Family's farmhouse would have been typical of the late 1800s, early 1900s regional rural setting. The home was constructed from native chesnut logs standing upon the stone foundation.
audioDescription: A old stone foundation in a level, hollowed out section of ground with a sign reading "farmhouse" in front of it.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 8: The Bank Barn

images.altText: A large forest clearing with a stone wall along the banks of a hillside.
images.title: The Bank Barn
images.caption: The barn ruins was once home to hogs, chickens, and sheep.

bodyText: The Brown Family's barn was constructed along the bank of the hillside in this forest clearing. The term "bank barn" comes from the use of the hillside as part of the first-floor walls and foundation. This sturcture is where the homestead maintained and cared for animals such as hogs, chickens, and sheep.
audioDescription: A large forest clearing with a stone wall along the banks of a hillside.

title: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 9: Forest Succession

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign reading "forest succession" standing in a growing forest.
images.title: Forest Succession
images.caption: The Brown's Farm Trail is an excellent place to understand the process o succession.

bodyText: From being once a farmstead to the growing ecosystem that it is today, the forest along the Brown's Farm Trail is a great place to witness the process of forest succession. As the forest matures, more hardwood saplings will take root and grow to dominate the landscape, replacing the pines, and eventaully culmintating in a climax state in which it will be considered an old-growth forest.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "forest succession" standing in a growing forest.

title: Camp Round Meadow Electric Vehicle Charging

images.altText: A white electric vehicle plugged into a standing charging station.
images.title: Electric Car Charging
images.caption: Camp Round Meadow provides a free charging station.

bodyText: Visitors are able to charge their vehicles at Camp Round Meadow. The charging equipment was provided through a grant from the Department of Energy to encourage the public’s use of electric vehicles, a part of the Clean Cities program.
audioDescription: A singular electric car charge station unit with two plug-in cables.

title: Catoctin Visitor Center Electric Vehicle Charging Station

images.altText: A man plugging in a power cable from an electric vehicle power station to a white car.
images.title: Electric Car Charging
images.caption: Electric vehicle charging equipment is available by the visitor center at Catoctin Mountain Park.

bodyText: Visitors are able to charge their vehicles near the visitor center, conveniently located at major trailheads. The charging equipment was provided through a grant from the Department of Energy to encourage the public’s use of electric vehicles, a part of the Clean Cities program.
audioDescription: A man plugging in a power cable from an electric vehicle power station to a white car.

title: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Collier's Hut

images.altText: A triangular shelter made of stacked logs and sticks.
images.title: Collier's Hut
images.caption: Colliers needed their huts to be close to the hearths the monitored.

bodyText: Because of the several charcoals hearths they had to monitor, colliers had to live nearby. Collier huts were very simple, small dwellings. They consisted of a triangular build of logs with a small door at the entrance and a stone cooking area in the back of the hut.
audioDescription: A triangular shelter made of stacked logs and sticks.

title: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Fueling the Furnace

images.altText: A wayside panel, next to a forest trail, describing historic iron production.
images.title: Fueling the Furnace
images.caption: The charcoal produced on the mountain was delivered to the Catoctin Iron Furnace.

bodyText: Once the charcoal had been produced, teamsters would transport it down the mountain to the Catoctin Iron Furnace. The charcoal would then be used to fuel the fuurnace in order to produce pig iron.
audioDescription: A wayside panel, next to a forest trail, describing historic iron production.

title: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Making Charcoal

images.altText: A wayside panel next to a clearing surrounded by a wooden fence.
images.title: Making Charcoal
images.caption: The charcoal burning process took a couple weeks.

bodyText: Once a hearth site had been prepared, the cords of wood assembled, covered with dust and leaves, and the fire had been lit at the center, a collier would monitor his hearth for 2 weeks untill all the wood was converted into charcoal.
audioDescription: A wayside panel next to a clearing surrounded by a wooden fence.

title: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Preparing the Hearth

images.altText: A forest clearing with a ring of stacked logs surrounding it.
images.title: Preparing the Hearth
images.caption: Charcoal hearths required a 30 to 40-foot clearing.

bodyText: The blackened soil of this forest clearing is an indication that it was once used as a hearth site, with the charcoal darkening the coloration of the soil. Because of the size of charcoal hearths, the clearing needed to be at least 30 to 40 feet in diameter. The area would need to be cleared and raked before the 4-foot logs were assembled into a hearth.
audioDescription: A forest clearing with a ring of stacked logs surrounding it.

title: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Wood - The Essential Ingredient

images.altText: A wayside panel, standing in a forest, describing historic logging.
images.title: Wood- The Essential Ingredient
images.caption: Historically, woodcutters on the mountain cleared the mountainside to produce cords of wood.

bodyText: During the peak of the charcoal indusrty, the mountain and surrounding areas looked very different. Woodcutters cleared most of the trees and the cords of wood produced were burned down into charcoal.
audioDescription: A wayside panel, standing in a forest, describing historic logging.

title: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Wood Hauler's Sled

images.altText: A large wooden sled resting on top of rocks alongside a trail in the forest.
images.title: Thurmont Vista Charcoal Trail
images.caption: Loaded with 4-foot logs, wooden sleds would haul cut wood to charcoal hearths.

bodyText: Hauled either by horses or mules, wood sleds would be loaded with 4-foot logs that would be transported from cutter sites to charcoal hearth clearings that dotted the mountainside. This work was done by a wide variety of people including whites, free blacks and slaves.
audioDescription: A large wooden sled resting on top of rocks alongside a trail in the forest.

title: Chestnut Picnic Area

images.altText: A forested picnic area wooden sign with the National Park Service logo.
images.title: Chestnut Picnic Area
images.caption: The Chestnut Picnic Area is an easily accessible recreation location with access to various trails.

bodyText: The Chestnut Picnic Area is a great place to start exploring the West Side trails of the park, including the Catoctin National Recreation Trail. Parking for horse trailers is next to the picnic area so that equestrians have easy access to the park Horse Trails.
audioDescription: A large forested picnic area with multiple tables and benches, restrooms, grills, a parking lot, as well as a hard woodcarpet accessible trail

title: Chestnut Picnic Area Restrooms

images.altText: Brown and white building with wheelchair accessible ramp
images.title: Chestnut Picnic Area Restrooms
images.caption: Chestnut Picnic Area Restrooms

bodyText: The restroom facility at the Chestnut Picnic Area is located in the center of the picnic area. Wheelchair-accessible trails from the parking areas lead directly to the restrooms. The restrooms have flush toilets and sinks with running water. This restroom facility is open seasonally.
audioDescription: A rectangular, brown-brick building with a white rooftop with restroom facilities for men and women.

title: Chimney Rock

images.altText: A jumble of large boulders is visible with a sweeping mountain view behind it.
images.title: Chimney Rock Overlook
images.caption: Please use caution when visiting Chimney Rock and keep pets and children away from crevasses.

bodyText: Chimney Rock is at about 1,400 feet in elevation and looks out to the east over the piedmont region. The ourcrop is part of the larger Weverton Formation, with the weather-resistant quartzite forming the "chimney" after millions of years of erosion.
audioDescription: This area is covered in rocks with uneven surfaces and crevasses. The most prominent rock is separated from the observation area and is roughly cylindrical, resembling a chimney. There is a view beyond the chimney of hills and valleys.

title: Cunningham Falls

images.altText: A large, white cascading waterfall flowing through large rocks in a green forest.
images.title: Cunningham Falls
images.caption: After a 2-mile hike from the visitor center, hikers are rewarded with a view of the falls.

bodyText:
Cunningham Falls is the largest cascading waterfall in the state of Maryland. Just across State Route 77 in Cunninham Falls State Park, hikers can access this scenic spot by taking the yellow trail from the visitor center. After a 1 mile hike, visitors can cross the road and talk a short boardwalk to the base of the falls.
A small, handicap pulloff parking lot is available by the boardwalk.
audioDescription: A large, cascading waterfall flowing through a large rock formation in a green forest.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 10: Stream

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign reading "stream," in front of a water crossing.
images.title: Owens Creek Stream Crossing
images.caption: Part of Deerfield Nature Trail Cross through Owens Creek.

bodyText: Owens Creek is an excellent habitat for aquatic and semi-aquactic wildlife. Many species of amphibians such as frogs, toads, and a plethora of different types of lungless salamander make their homes in and along the stream.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "stream," in front of a water crossing.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 11: Japanese Barberry

images.altText: A long stem of small lobbed leaves with small cream colored flowers.
images.title: Japanese Barberry
images.caption: Japanese barberry is a problematic invasive species.

bodyText: Japanese barberry are an invasive plant species in Catoctin Mountain Park. The throny shrub spreads easily with the help of humans from being carried along shoes.  It was first introduced in the 1860s/1870s as an ornamental shrub and escaped to the wild where it tolerates shade, severe drought, and extreme winters. Barberry also is prime habitat for ticks which are vectors for lyme disease.
audioDescription: A long stem of small lobbed leaves with small cream colored flowers.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 12: Shagbark Hickory

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign reading "hickory," in front of a tree with loose, shaggy bark.
images.title: Shagbark Hickory
images.caption: Shagbark hickory is a valuable tree species to many mammals.

bodyText: Shagbark hickories are easy to identify from their titular bark which is "shaggy" in appearance. The loose barkprovides shelter for bats during the daytime and hickory nuts are a vaulable food resource to many mammals.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "hickory," in front of a tree with loose, shaggy bark.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 13: Christmas Fern

images.altText: A close up shot of a broad green fern leaf.
images.title: Christmas Fern
images.caption: Christmas ferns are evergreen plants that prefer damp soil.

bodyText: The Deerfield Nature Trail is an excellent location to see Christmas ferns. The evergreen ferns thrive in the damp soils that surround Owens Creek.
audioDescription: A close up shot of a broad green fern leaf.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 14: Marginal Wood Fern

images.altText: A large cluster of ferns growing around a downed log in a shaded forest, with a streak of light.
images.title: Marginal Wood Ferns
images.caption: Marginal wood ferns are an evergreen plant found across the mountain.

bodyText: Marginal wood ferns are an evergreen species that can be found growing throughout the park. It prefers to grow in rocky areas with sufficient moisture.
audioDescription: A large cluster of ferns growing around a downed log in a shaded forest, with a streak of light cutting across them.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 15: Tulip Poplar Tree

images.altText: Large, green-lobbed leaves surrounding a yellow and orange flower.
images.title: Tulip Poplar
images.caption: Tulip poplars are one of the largest trees found in the park.

bodyText: Not only are tulip poplars one of the fastest growing trees in the park, but they are also one of the tallest at 100 feet in height. These trees play an important role in forest succession as they quickly create a forest canopy, shading the understory and gradually overtime they will be replaced by mature hardwoods such as oak, beech, and maple trees.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "tulip polar," in front of a tree with orange and yellow blazes.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 1: Rhyolite Outcrop

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign reading "rhyolite outcrop," in front of a pill of dark gray and brown rocks.
images.title: Rhyolite Outcrop
images.caption: Rhyolite was an important tool making resource for American Indians.

bodyText: Prior to the arrival of European settlers in the region, Catoctin Mountain Park was used by American Indians for quarrying rhyolite to create stone tools. Rhyolite outcrops are common on the western side of the park and the rocks were ideal to knap into spear points and arrowheads.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "rhyolite outcrop," in front of a pill of dark gray and brown rocks.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 2: Bear Corn

images.altText: Cream colored plant bulbs with brownish scales, emerging from leaf litter.
images.title: Bear Corn
images.caption: Bear corn is a food source for many forest animals.

bodyText: Known by many names (bear corn, squawroot, or American cancer-root), bear corn is a parasitic plant that can be found growing around oak and beech trees. Lacking chlorophyll to photosynthesize, the plant relies on nutrients taken from its host tree. The yellow seed pods it produces are a food source for a wide variety of forest animals.
audioDescription: Cream colored plant bulbs with brownish scales, emerging from leaf litter.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 3: Coppiced Trees

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reading "coppiced trees," standing in front of a grove of trees.
images.title: Coppiced Trees
images.caption: Coppiced Trees are evidence of the logging done by the charcoal industry in the past.

bodyText: The production of pig iron at the Catoctin Iron Furnace was fueled by the charcoal made from from the trees logged across the mountain. Majority of the forest was cut down and some of the remaining stumps grew out, causing many trees to have multiple trunks.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign reading "coppiced trees," standing in front of a grove of trees.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 4: Beech Tree Burl

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reading "tree burl," in front of a tree with a large growth on its trunk.
images.title: Beech Tree Burl
images.caption: Burls form over damaged sections of the tree.

bodyText: When a tree experiences some type of stress in its wood, a burl will form over the damaged or distrubed area. Burls can be caused by a variety of factors such as damage from insects, viruses, or environmental conditions. Burls can form on any part of the tree, even underground where damage can be more prevelant to the roots. A tree can still grow and fully function with burls.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign reading "tree burl," in front of a tree with a large growth on its trunk.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 5: Owens Creek

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reading "owens creek," on a ridge above a flowing stream.
images.title: Owens Creek
images.caption: Take a moment to listen to Owens Creek wind through the forest.

bodyText: Owens Creek flows across the western side of Catoctin Mountain Park and is the centerpiece of the Deerfield Nature Trail. Its clear freshwater has been a valuable resource for American Indians, native plants and animals, and European settlers alike.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign reading "owens creek," on a ridge above a flowing stream.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 6: Decomposition

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reading "decomposition," in front of a decaying log.
images.title: Decomposition
images.caption: Decomposition is an important part of nutrient cycling in the forest.

bodyText: In death, as in life, trees provide both food and shelter for many species. Over time, a collection of bacteria, fungi, and insects will break down trees into organic matter which will return to the soil providing nutirents for the next generation of plants.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign reading "decomposition," in front of a decaying log.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 7: Northern Spicebush

images.altText: Broad green leaves surrounding a small, red, oval shaped berry.
images.title: Spicebush
images.caption: Spicebush can be seen throughout the park.

bodyText: The northern spicebush is abundant throughout the park. The understory shrub provides food and habitat for creatures ranging from spicebush catepillar (and spicebush swallowtail butterflies) to white-tailed deer.
audioDescription: Broad green leaves surrounding a small, red, oval shaped berry.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 8: The Stone Wall

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign reading "stone wall," standing in front of a long wall made of stacked stones.
images.title: Stone Wall
images.caption: Stone walls can be found across the park, remnants of an agricultural past.

bodyText: Dating back to the 1700s, the region was cleared for homesteads and other land uses. Local rocks such as greenstone and rhyolite were used in the consturction of farm boundaries and home foundations. These foundations can still be found throughout the park, but now nature is slowly growing over them as they serve as habitat and shelter for wildlife.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign reading "stone wall," standing in front of a long wall made of stacked stones.

title: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 9: Sugar Maple

images.altText: A tree with reddish leaves that have multiple pointed lobes.
images.title: Sugar Maple
images.caption: Sugar Maples are a mature hardwood forest tree.

bodyText: Sugar maples are one of the more colorful trees in eastern deciduous hardwood forests during the fall. Their leaves range on a spectrum from yellow to red. Sugar Maples have also been historically used by American Indians and European settlers for their sap, which when boiled down can be turned into maple syrup. It takes around 40 gallons of sap to make 1 gallon of syrup,
audioDescription: A tree with reddish leaves that have multiple pointed lobes.

title: Hog Rock

images.altText: A broad, flat rock creates an opening to view the valley below, surrounded by green trees.
images.title: Hog Rock Overlook
images.caption: Hog Rock is a popular overlook that can be part of a variety of different length hikes.

bodyText: Hog Rock affords a view to the east of the mountains of the Weverton Formation and of the gap through which Hunting Creek flows.
audioDescription: A broad, mostly flat rock creates an opening in the trees to provide a view of the valley below.

title: Hog Rock Parking Area Restroom

images.altText: Wooden Structure with concrete ramp and sidewalk. The structure is located directy next to several p
images.title: Hog Rock Parking Area Restroom
images.caption: Hog Rock Parking Area Restroom

bodyText: The Hog Rock Parking Area Restroom is a single vault toilet restroom with no running water. This facility is located directly adjacent to the parking area and is wheelchair accessible. This restroom facility is located along Park Central Road 1.8 miles away from the Visitor Center.
audioDescription: A large parking lot for about 25 cars, on the east side is the trailhead to the Blue Ridge Summit Trail and the pit toilet. The restroom is a permanent structure with a roof overhanging a concrete walkway. It has one restroom stall.

title: Lewis Pond

images.altText: A small pond in front of a fall forest.
images.title: Lewis Pond
images.caption: The Lewis Pond is a peaceful spot to relax.

bodyText:
The Lewis Pond is a peaceful water feature on the southeastern edge of the park in the Lewis Area. Visitors can relax on the water's edge and fish, enjoy the cool shade of the trees, or start out on a hike on the Gateway Trail which leads into the larger park. 

Fishing at the Lewis Pond has no tackle restrictions. Statewide regulations for bass and sunfish apply.
audioDescription: A small pond next to a forest.

title: Owens Creek Picnic Area

images.altText: A wooden National Park Service sign on a roadside in a forested area.
images.title: Owens Creek Picnic Area
images.caption: Nestled on the western side of the park, the Owens Creek Picnic Area provides access to many trails.

bodyText: Quiet, calm, and scenic. The Owens Creek Picnic Area provides a wide variety of things to do for park patrons. With multiple picnic tables and grills, people can sit beneath the shade of the forest to relax and eat. The picnic area is a great place to start your exploration of the West Side trails of the park, including the Catoctin National Recreation Trail and the Browns Farm Trail. For those interested in history, the Owens Creek Saw Mill is also nearby.
audioDescription: A forested parking lot with access to multiple wooden picnic tables, a vaulted toilet with multiple woodland trails in the vicinity.

title: Owens Creek Picnic Area Restrooms

images.altText: Brown building by parking area with two doors. The doors are labeled with restroom signs.
images.title: Owens Creek Picnic Area Restroom
images.caption: Owens Creek Picnic Area Restroom

bodyText: The wheelchair accessible restroom located at the Owens Creek Picnic Area is a vault toilet restroom with no running water. The restroom facility is located adjacent to several parking spaces on the upper side of the picnic area. For hikers, this restroom facility is located near the Brown’s Farm Loop Trail, the Deerfield Nature Trail, and a section of the Horse Trail. This restroom facility is open seasonally.
audioDescription: The area is a narrow parking lot in a picnic area, with two permanent pit toilets. The road and parking spaces are paved, the picnic area has wood chip paths to the tables and grills.

title: Owens Creek Sawmill

images.altText: A large open, wooden-roof building with a log and water wheel towards the center.
images.title: Owens Creek Sawmill Exhibit
images.caption: The reconstructed sawmill at Owens Creek Campground provides an up-close view of the gears.

bodyText:
Water-powered sawmills were usually built by entrepreneurs who owned forested land and a little money to invest into a family run business. The lumber cut was used for the building of homes, towns, and barns. Some of the lumber was exported to other countries. The old sawmills with their slow production of about 48 planks for a 12 hour day at best, are long gone. The mill pits and banks of the races stand in mute testimony to the long hours and hard work that once marked these sites.

The exact date of construction and first operation of the vertical sawmill near today's Owens Creek Campground is unknown, but it is shown on an 1857 map with the same area indicated as deeded back to 1808, mentioning rights to water ways. The same 1857 map also shows 4 additional sawmills on Owens Creek and one on Big Hunting Creek near the present day Visitor Center.

The sawmill near the present day Owens Creek Campground probably operated until after the late 1890's. A reconstruction of the mill was built by the Youth Conservation Corps on the site of the original sawmill. Construction of the campground eliminated the possibility of water power operations, but the gears and what would have been underwater works are all visible from an accessible boardwalk.
audioDescription: A large open, wooden-roof building with a log and water wheel towards the center. On the side of the building is a connected wheelchair accessible wooden ramp.

title: Peniel (Park Headquarters)

images.altText: A stone pillar with the words "Camp Peniel" engraved on a flat furface.
images.title: Camp Peniel
images.caption: Park Headquarters serves as a great access point to the trails.

bodyText: Historic Camp Peniel serves as the park's central headquarters. From the parking lot just off State Route 77, hikers can access the trails to Chimney Rock, the Lewis Area, and the Visitor Center.
audioDescription: A stone pillar with the words "Camp Peniel" engraved on a smooth surface.

title: Safety at Catoctin Mountain Park

images.altText: A coiled tan and brown snake with a rattle at the end of its tail.
images.title: Timber Rattlesnake
images.caption: Timber Rattlesnakes are one of two venomous snake species found in the park.

bodyText:
Hiking Conditions & Precautions


Catoctin Mountain Park is a fun and exciting place to explore. Chimney Rock is one of the most popular hiking destinations with spectacular views of the valley below. However, please be advised that jumping across the rocks is extremely dangerous. People are seriously injured at Chimney Rock on a frequent basis. The size of the gaps between rocks is very deceptive, so please do not attempt to jump these hazard areas!

Use caution while hiking. Many of the trails are rocky and uneven. Wear sturdy shoes or hiking boots and watch where you're going to avoid slips, falls, and possible strains and sprains. Dress for the weather. Wear layers of clothing in cold weather and carry water while hiking in all seasons. Pick up a park map at the visitor center before exploring the trails or download one from this website.

Poison Ivy is a common plant in the park and many people suffer an itchy rash after contact. It has 3 shiny dark leaves and also can be a thick hairy vine.
 

Wildlife


Close encounters with wildlife should be avoided. The speed limit throughout the park is 30 mph. This speed will help you enjoy the scenery and watch wildlife and lessen the chance of a collision with the resident wildlife. Deer in particular often travel in groups so if you see one cross the road, slow down and look for another to soon follow behind. Black bears also inhabit the park, so if you happen to encounter one be sure to maintain a resepctful distance. Slowly back away in the direction you came if you see a bear walking on the trail. When camping be sure to secure your food items properly to avoid attracting wildlife.

There are two venomous snakes found in the park: the copperhead and the timber rattlesnake. Please remember that all wildlife have a role in the ecosystem and are protected from harassment and harm. These snakes will only strike when threatened and/or provoked.

Ticks are also found in the park. The small deer tick which can carry Lyme Disease, and the dog tick which can carry Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever. Long sleeve shirts, long pants, socks, and a hat offer good protection. Check your entire body after a visit to make sure you didn't take home any unwanted travelers!

In case of emergency call Emergency Dispatch at:
1-866-677-6677 or dial 911


Do not rely on cellular phones as not all types work in the park. Check your coverage to be sure you are covered!

If you have any questions or concerns, please just ask a park ranger or call the visitor center at (301) 663-9388.
audioDescription: A coiled tan and brown snake with a rattle at the end of its tail.

title: The Round Meadow Rain Garden

images.altText: An information panel with written and visual descriptions on the functions of a rain garden.
images.title: Camp Round Meadow Rain Garden Wayside
images.caption: Learn about the importance of rain gardens in a watershed!

bodyText: If you happen to spend time up at Camp Round Meadow you may notice the presence of a rain garden. Not only does it serve an important role in protecting the Owens Creek Watershed, but it also serves as a teaching tool. Take some time to read the wayside panel about the functions of the plants in the Round Meadow Rain Garden.
audioDescription: An information panel with written and visual descriptions on the functions of a rain garden.

title: Thurmont Vista

images.altText: A bench sits in a gravel clearing in front of an overlook facing farms and towns.
images.title: Thurmont Vista Overlook
images.caption: Thurmont Vista is a somewhat steep hike, but the view is worth it!

bodyText: The Thurmont Vista, with an elevation of 1,502 feet, is a relatively short steep climb. The view here is to the east of the Frederick Valley and Thurmont.
audioDescription: A wooden bench with stone pillars rests on a bare patch surrounded by brush and trees. Over the shrubbery, there is a view of a valley with patches cleared for farms and towns. The trees and shrubs vary widely from towering old hardwoods with thick trunks to patches of grassy wildflowers.

title: Trailhead: Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail

images.altText: A black, vertical panel reading "Blue Blazes Whiskey Trail" next to a wooden bridge over a stream.
images.title: The Blue Blazes
images.caption: The Blues Blazes Trail is a short, easy hike along a stream.

bodyText:
The Blue Blazes Trail is 0.3 miles one-way. Roundtrip to and from the Whiskey Still Exhibit from the trailhead is 0.6 miles. 

The Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail is accessed from the gravel parking lot across from the visitor center. The trailhead begins just before the wooden footbridge at the northwest corner of the gravel parking lot. As you travel along the Blue Blazes creek, interpretive trailside signs explore stream ecology and the history of whiskey production on Catoctin Mountain during the time of Prohibition. The trail concludes at an actual whiskey still.
audioDescription: A black, vertical panel reading "Blue Blazes Whiskey Trail" next to a wooden bridge over a stream.

title: Trailhead: Blue Ridge Summit

images.altText: A wooden bulletin board next to a wooden map kiosk alongside a forested trail.
images.title: Blue Ridge Overlook Trail
images.caption: Hiking only a short distance from the Hog Rock Parking lot provides a view into Pennsylvania.

bodyText:
The hike from the parking lot to the vista is 0.3 miles and 0.6 miles round trip. It is part of the larger Yellow Blaze loop wihich is 4.6 miles.

The Blue Ridge Summit Vista is most readily accessible from the Hog Rock Parking Area. Picnic tables and a comfort station (pit toilet) are located at this parking area. From the Hog Rock Parking area, expect one hill to climb to reach the mass of boulders that make up the vista area.
audioDescription: A wooden bulletin board next to a wooden map kiosk alongside a forested trail.

title: Trailhead: Browns Farm North Terminus

images.altText: A small brown sign post next to a forested trail.
images.title: Browns Farm North Trailhead
images.caption: The Browns Farm trail provides a peaceful look into Catoctin's forests.

bodyText:
The Browns Farm Trail starts wiith a 0.4 mile loop starting and leading back to the Owens Creek Picnic Area, marked by a white triangle blaze. The trail itself continues south for 0.5 miles, marked by a white rectangle blaze from the southern junction of the loop, ending at Camp Round Meadow.

Starting near the Owens Creek Parking Area, follow the Browns Farm Nature Trail south as it winds through dense hardwood forests, pine groves, and the abandoned Browns Farm.
audioDescription: A small brown sign post next to a forested trail.

title: Trailhead: Catoctin National Recreation Trail

images.altText: Wooden trailhead sign next to a dirt path through a green forest.
images.title: Catoctin National Recreation Trail
images.caption: The Recreation Trail connects Gambrill State Park in the south to Cactotin Mountain Park northward.

bodyText:
This trail is marked by a blue blaze with 4.75 miles within the boundaries of the park.

The north trailhead is in Catoctin Mountatin Park and lies within three miles of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. Along its route the trail crosses a State Scenic Byway and parallels the Catoctin Mountain National Scenic Byway. There are historic districts (Camp Greentop and Camp Misty Mount) as well as historic and prehistoric archeological resources along the trail, including Indian flint napping sites and Colonial era charcoal hearths. In addition to skirting several lakes, the trail also accessess numerous scenic vistas with views of the Monocacy River Valley. The entire trail runs for 26 miles, connecting Catoctin Mountain Park, Cunningham Falls State Park, Frederick City Municipal Forest, and Gambrill State Park.
audioDescription: A 26.6 mile long trail that moves along the forested mountain ridge. It passes through historic sites of wooden cabins built on the forested mountainside as well as passing man made lakes and ponds.

title: Trailhead: Charcoal Exhibit Trail

images.altText: A tall wayside panel next to a forested trail.
images.title: Charcoal Exhibit Trail
images.caption: The Charcoal Exhibit Trail provides a glimpse into the industry that once dominated the mountain.

bodyText:
This trail is a one-half mile loop.

The trail will take you along several exhibits and displays that will tell the story of the once thriving charcoal making industry on the mountain. The trail is readily accessible from the Thurmont Vista Parking Area. The Charcoal Exhibit Trail can also be accessed from the nearby Thurmont Vista Trail (Blazed Pink/Purple Rectangle) or from the Hog Rock Loop Trail
(Blazed Yellow Rectangle.)
audioDescription: A forested trail that forms a loop passing through multiple historical exhibits in the forest.

title: Trailhead: Chimney Rock & Wolf Rock

images.altText: A large brown sign, next to a forested trail pointing in varying directions with trail distances.
images.title: Chimney Rock Trailhead
images.caption: The Chimney Rock Trailhead meets up with various trails

bodyText:
This trail system is marked by a orange blaze and follows a loop for 3.9 miles. 

This loop trail contains the most strenuous sections of trail in the park. Expect uneven and rocky terrain from the river valley areas of the Visitor Center and Park Headquarters as you hike approx. 600 feet in elevation to the mountain ridgeline where Chimney Rock and Wolf Rock are located.

Please use caution when walking along rock surfaces. These areas can be slippery.
Closely supervise children at all times. Watch for rattlesnakes in the areas of Chimney Rock and Wolf Rock.
audioDescription: A large brown sign, next to a forested trail and stone steps, pointing in varying directions with trail distances.

title: Trailhead: Cunningham Falls Nature Trail

images.altText: A brown wooden sign with directions for two trailheads, standing in a forest.
images.title: Falls Nature Trail
images.caption: The hike to the falls is one of the most popular trails in the park.

bodyText:
The Cunningham Falls Nautre Trail is 2.8 miles round trip from the visitor center to the falls and back. 

The Falls Nature Trail is accessed from the gravel parking lot directly across from the visitor center. The trail begins at the back of the gravel parking lot on the right hand side and crosses Md. Rt. 77 1.1 miles from the Visitor Center. The most popular trail in the park, this trail takes visitors to the largest cascading waterfall in Maryland. Expect multiple hills uneven and rocky surfaces.

Note: The Cunningham Falls are located within the boundaries of Cunningham Falls State Park and State Park regulations and guidelines apply.
audioDescription: A brown wooden sign with directions for two trailheads, standing in a forest.

title: Trailhead: Deerfield Nature

images.altText: A wooden sign reading "Deerfield Nature Trail" next to a forested trail.
images.title: Deerfield Nature Trail
images.caption: Short, scenic, and informative. The Deerfield Nature Trail is a great place for families to explore.

bodyText:
The trail follows a loop that is 1.3 miles with mild changes in elevation.

The Deerfield Nature Trail provides a soothing hike filled with informative panels which describe the local forest ecology and history. This trail is marked by a yellow triangle.
audioDescription: A wooden sign reading "Deerfield Nature Trail" next to a forested trail.

title: Trailhead: Gateway Trail

images.altText: Small brown post with a sticker reading "gateway trail" next to a tree with a white blaze.
images.title: Gateway Trail
images.caption: Living up to it's name, the Gateway Trail provides access to the larger park leading from Thurmont.

bodyText:
This trail is 3.9 miles and is marked by a white blaze.

Accessible from the Visitor Center, Park Headquarters, or from the Lewis Property Parking Area, the Gateway Trail in Catoctin Mountain Park
offers a challenging hike through rocky and hilly terrain. Coming from the Lewis Property Parking Area, one is offered the opportunity to parallel Big Hunting Creek or to summit the mountain near Chimney Rock. Alternatively, the Gateway Trail can lead you off park lands and into the community of Thurmont.
audioDescription: Small brown post with a sticker reading "gateway trail" next to a tree with a white blaze.

title: Trailhead: Hog Rock

images.altText: A brown, wooden sign alongside a forested dirt trail.
images.title: Hog Rock Nature Trail
images.caption: The Hog Rock Nature Trail is a short hike to the highest vista in the park

bodyText:
This section of the yellow trail is 1 mile, the entire Yellow Blaze runs for 4.6 miles.

An extension of the Hog Rock Loop Trail, the Hog Rock Nature Trail is most readily accessed from the Hog Rock Parking Area off of Park Central Road. Picnic tables and a comfort station (pit toilet) are located at this parking area. As you venture into the woods, labeled posts, which accompanies a brochure guide (obtained at the trailhead or Visitor Center) identifies several
features you will discover along the trail. Expect a few small hills, uneven surfaces, and several rocky features along the hike.
audioDescription: A short interactive dirt trail through mountainous woodland which passes through a large rock outcropping overlooking the mountain ridge.

title: Trailhead: Horse Trail

images.altText: A dark brown horse with white stripe markings and a tan horse tethered to a wooden post in a forest.
images.title: Horses on the Trail
images.caption: Horses love getting out on the trails of the west side of the park.

bodyText:
Approximately 6 miles of trails are maintained in Catoctin Mountain Park for public horseback riding. These trails are identified with a Orange Triangle Blaze. The section of the Catoctin National Recreation Trail North of Park Central Road also accommodates equestrian use.

Trailer parking is available across from the entrance to Camp Greentop. If the parking area is snow covered or muddy, horse trailers should be parked at Round Meadow and horses led or ridden along the shoulder of Park Central Road to the trails.
audioDescription: A dark brown horse with white stripe markings and a tan horse, tethered to a wooden post in a forest, resting alongside a trail.

title: Trailhead: Spicebush Trail

images.altText: A brown compacted special access trail winding through a forest.
images.title: Spicebush Nature Trail
images.caption: The Spicebush Nature Trail is wheelchair-accessible with WoodCarpet® that is firm and stable.

bodyText:
This trail loop is around 0.2 miles.

Easily accessed from the Chestnut Picnic Area, the Spicebush Nature Trail is a wheelchair-accessible loop that has wayside panels describing the natural histroy of the mountain's forests.
audioDescription: A brown compacted special access trail winding through a forest.

title: Trailhead: Thurmont Vista

images.altText: A large tree trunk with a pink colored blaze on its side, standing next to a trail in a forest.
images.title: Thurmont Vista Loop Trail
images.caption: This is a moderate trail with both uphill and downhill sections.

bodyText:
The Thurmont Vista Loop Trail is 2.6 miles. 

Most readily accessible from the Thurmont Vista Parking Area, the short yet moderately challenging hike will crest the mountain ridgeline at the Thurmont Vista. The Charcoal Exhibit Trail can also be accessed nearby as well as the Hog Rock Loop Trail (Blazed Yellow Rectangle).
audioDescription: A large tree trunk with a pink colored blaze on its side, standing next to a trail in a forest.

title: Trailhead: Wolf Rock
bodyText:
The trail distance to Wolf Rock is 1 mile. This trail is part of the larger 3.9 mile Orange Blaze Loop.

Accessed from a small pull-off parking lot along Park Central Road, the Wolf Rock Trailhead is a good access point to mutliple trails across the park. From this trail junction, hikers can either travel to Wolf Rock or link up with the Pink and Yellow trails to reach Thurmont, Blue Ridge Summit, and Hog Rock vistas.
audioDescription: A brown, wooden sign standing in a snowy forest, providing directions to chimney and wolf rocks.

title: Wolf Rock
listingDescription: Wolf Rock at Catoctin Mountain Park

images.altText: A large boulder in the shape of a wolf.
images.title: Wolf Rock
images.caption: Do you see the wolf?

bodyText: Wolf Rock is a boulder field featuring a wolf-shaped boulder. The boulder field is part of the Weverton Formation which was deposited as sand 550 million years ago. After sediment layers covered the formation 250 million years ago, the formation would crystalize with the uplifting of the Appalachain Mountains and erosion revealed the quartzite present today. The whole field is the size of a football field, but parts are grown over and parts are inaccessible due to crevasses. Please use caution while exploring the Wolf Rock area.
audioDescription: Boulders cover the landscape, one shaped vaguely like a wolf's profile. There are many uneven surfaces and deep crevasses, some of which have spindly trees growing out.
